head.title: Journal Kept at Slave Lake, 1802. - Page #9

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #9 of 16 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Wentzel, Willard Ferdinand. Journal Kept at Slave Lake, 1802. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0013

div.p: Thursday 30th[.] Sent off two young men to Trois Pouce with ½ fm: Tobacco[.] A hard Heavy rain all Day[.] [T]he Potties returned from L'Isle D'Orignal they brought 28 Trouts & 50 White Fish[.] Traded 8 Skins of meat[.] Gave about 6 phiuls of rum to the Indians that arrived yesterday[.]

Friday October 1st[.] A hard snow all Day[.] => I forgot to mention when Tourcotte arrived that he had been Sick with the Indians that they carried him in Several Campments – he is still unable to work[.]
Saturday 2nd[.] Rain all Day no visiting the nets owing to the bad weather[.] The Indians begin to grow impatient & threatens to take Credits from the Potties[.]
Sunday 3rd[.] Early in the morning Piché arrived from the Indians brought 6 Skins of meat[.] Snowing Continually[.]

Monday 4th[.] At Sun Rise John returned from the Indians brought letters from Athabasca that he had taken from Cent-Sols who was sent from Athabasca to advertise us of the Potties arriv[al.] John left them at the Grande Isle[.] I recieved 4 fms. Tobacco[.] I cannot help remarking that Mr D. McKenzies letters caused many wry faces here – consequently many discontents remain to be pleased[.] About 3 Hours after 2 Canoes of the Potties well mann'd (viz 11) & loaded – one of their Bourquois named McKenzie & a Clerk called Smith[.] What we counted for Pieces is the following, 13 Bales, 17 Kegs, 1 Case Guns, 3 Case Irons, 1 Case Knives, 6 rolls ScTobacco, 1 Bale Kettles, 1 bale Carrots, 2 Cassettes, 2 bags flour, 6 Balls Shot & ball, 1 Case, 1 Cass 1 Basket & several bags of God Knows what[.] About an hour after his arrival he Sent over Perronne & Smith & invited John & I of course we went over & Drank a Dish of Tea – & eat a little meat cut up in small pieces & boil'd in water without either pepper, Salt, or Grease[.] After the table was taken away he produced a flaggon of Shrub, & 1 of spirits, we fell to, as if we were at home[.] The discourse happen'd to fall on Mr the Knight – upon my calling Mr instead of Sir – the Cout fin took me up – Saying – "It is no more Mr but Alexander Sir Alexander, for he has published h[is] Journal of the N. West Passage to the Sea for which he [was]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
